title: Argument lifetimes appear to not be automatically shortened to those of a local variable
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:
```rust
fn test(mut vec: Vec<&u64>, val: u64) {
    vec.push(&val);
}
```
And this code:
```rust
fn test(mut vec: Vec<&u64>, val: u64) {
    let mut vec = vec;
    vec.push(&val);
}
```

I expected both snippets to be equivalent and compile.
Instead, only the second snippet compiles and the first one complains that `val` does not live long enough:
```rust
error[E0597]: `val` does not live long enough
  --> src\tree.rs:41:14
   |
40 | fn test(mut vec: Vec<&u64>, val: u64) {
   |                      - let's call the lifetime of this reference `'1`
41 |     vec.push(&val);
   |     ---------^^^^-
   |     |        |
   |     |        borrowed value does not live long enough
   |     argument requires that `val` is borrowed for `'1`
42 | }
   | - `val` dropped here while still borrowed
```

It seems as if the lifetimes of arguments are not shortened to those of a local variable.

To me this seems to be a compiler bug, because intuitively arguments are a subset of the local variables.
